useCaseType: Trust & Privacy Negotiation (Sensor Data, Data Sharing)
name: Consent-Driven Data Privacy Management
description: Olivia controls and restricts ALFRED’s data collection and sharing, ensuring no personal or sensor data is shared with third parties or caregivers, addressing her strong privacy concerns while enabling safe, user-driven interaction.
scenario:
Olivia, a retired social worker, has always been cautious about technology, especially when it comes to her personal data. When she first received the ALFRED system, she approached it with skepticism, determined to maintain strict control over what information was collected and shared. From the outset, Olivia insisted that ALFRED’s voice assistant only activate when she explicitly used the push-to-talk feature, refusing any unsolicited prompts or explanations about its features. She found the idea of constant notifications intrusive and overwhelming, so she configured ALFRED to suppress almost all alerts, especially those related to exercise or health check-ins she found challenging or uncomfortable.

Despite her reluctance, Olivia recognized the practical benefits of having ALFRED assist with everyday tasks, but she was adamant no sensor data from wearables should be transmitted to anyone—not her family, caregivers, or medical staff. She manually blocked all app installations unless she made a special request, wary of any third-party involvement. ALFRED respected her preferences, prompting only formal, polite language in all interactions, including messages to her daughter, whom Olivia communicated with sparingly and in a strictly formal tone.

This rigid stance put some strain on the system’s usual care coordination features. ALFRED’s default behavior to share health data with caregivers was disabled, which meant that her informal support network had fewer insights into her well-being. Olivia often dismissed video check-ins arranged by caregivers, preferring offline visits or phone calls that felt less intrusive. Occasionally, ALFRED would gently remind her about medication or appointments, but only when she explicitly asked, respecting her desire to avoid feeling monitored.

The tension between Olivia’s strong privacy concerns and the system’s potential to provide proactive care underscored her challenging relationship with ALFRED. While she appreciated the independence ALFRED offered, her deep mistrust of data sharing meant she navigated the system cautiously, using it strictly as a tool rather than a companion. ALFRED adapted to her firm boundaries, enabling her to maintain control, even if it limited the full range of benefits the system could provide.
